answers.author: Pooja Varma
answers.text:
Hi Tom, 
The Technology topic page of the Knowledge Network contains documents that discuss upgrading and management of IT. Here are a few that should be useful. 
Managing Information Technology Development – Los Angeles case study on the methodology of project management used by the City to upgrade its information technology. 
http://icma.org/en/icma/knowledge_network/documents/kn/Document/9217/Managing_Information_Technology_Development 
Information Technology Investment Priorities – Seattle’s plan indicates the priorities for IT investments, goals for improving services and increasing coordination across departments for procurement of technology applications. 
http://icma.org/en/icma/knowledge_network/documents/kn/Document/6220/Information_Technology_Investment_Priorities 
Information Technology Department Strategic Plan – provides the Westminister, Colorado strategic plan for the IT department and outlines performance measures, and technology acquisition. 
http://icma.org/en/icma/knowledge_network/documents/kn/Document/1782/Information_Technology_Department_Strategic_Plan
I hope this is useful,
Pooja Varma
International City/County Management Association
Knowledge Network Intern
pvarma@icma.org

author: Tom Nosack
text:
We are a mid-sized city with a high degree of high quality automation and continue to pursue more ways to get more effectiveness from our staff through the use of software and hardware as "force multipliers". It has generally worked well, as we are meeting community needs fairly well with staffing levels that are either lean or extraordinarly lean depending on how you look at it. 
One area we need to be mroe successful in is the organization of our IT function and the oversight of our IT purchasing and long term concept. We do not do as well as we should with deconflicting, coordinating, or takign advantages of software strengths as we add adjacent or new layers of systems. It becomes hard to decide if we need version 15 of product A for Finance, the upgrade to software B for Parks & Rec, or if we should make a slightly risky investment for a potentially high return in police for software C.  We aren't even talking about the incomplete work or bug fixes we don't have time to complete from initial installation of software D two years ago....
Who feels like they have a great organization and oversight that prioritizes well? How do organizations compete for the resources, and who keeps it all together in a way that makes sense over time?
Who has a great system that works well?
Thanks
